Award.AwardTitle: LSAMP BRIDGE TO THE DOCTORATE - ILLINOIS LSAMP BRIDGE TO THE DOCTORATE AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS AT CHICAGO 2013-2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central goal of the Illinois Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation Bridge to the Doctorate Program at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) is to increase the number of underserved populations who attain access to graduate education. The program provides Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) students with the academic and professional social skills to function at the highest levels of competency. Pre-matriculation, staff and faculty monitoring, research lab rotations, research projects and professional interactions along with intensive evaluation protocol helps to ensure that these students complete their PhD or MD/PhD. Upon completion of the program, the BD students will be ready to go into a postdoctoral program at any institution in the country or to obtain upper level STEM employment. One of the creative aspects of these activities is the inclusion of MD/PhDs among the cadre of PhD students that are being produced.

The Illinois LSAMP BD Program at UIC has four primary objectives:

1. To recruit a minimum of twelve highly motivated students from local and regional LSAMP alliances to UIC PhD programs;
2. To prepare matriculating BD Fellows to study and train towards the PhD;
3. To facilitate activities that will encourage BD Fellows to persist in PhD studies; and
4. To implement a series of activities designed to enhance the education and training of Illinois LSAMP BD Fellows and help them transition to postdoctoral fellowships, placement in the academy, or other positions requiring doctoral level STEM education.

Ethnic minorities comprise a disproportionately small fraction of graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and faculty in the STEM disciplines, including health sciences. The Illinois LSAMP BD Program at UIC will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups including women, ethnic and racial minorities. The program will not only help to close the gap created by the paucity of underrepresented individuals who are functioning creatively at the PhD level, it will also encourage others who have been reticent to attempt graduate work because of the lack of qualified role models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Illinois LSAMP Bridge to the Doctorate at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) Project Outcomes (9/1/2013 – 8/31/2017).

Illinois LSAMP: The Illinois Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (ILSAMP) comprises of nine four-year institutions and four two-year colleges. Chicago State University (CSU) is the lead institution for the Illinois LSAMP program. Through very strategic programming, the ILSAMP has successfully increased the number of underrepresented minority students graduating in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics). Some of the graduates either join the STEM workforce or matriculate into graduate STEM programs.  Through the NSF Directorate for Education and Human Resources, the ILSAMP has supported seven Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) cohorts at UIC in an effort to increase the number of underrepresented minorities earning terminal (Ph.D.) degrees since 2006. To-date, a total of 66 students have enrolled in the program, 31 of whom are currently enrolled while 28 of them (all minorities) have completed Ph.D. degrees. Thus, the addition of the BD initiative has expanded the potential of the Illinois Alliance to address the opposite end of the service spectrum and the opportunity to complete the education cycle with a terminal degree.  As a result of the maturation process, the Alliance has developed and implemented a comprehensive network of programming, encouraging students from middle school, high school, college and through to the completion of the Ph.D. STEM degree and career in the academia and research.

Intellectual Merits: UIC BD activities are designed to accomplish the central goal of increasing the number of underrepresented persons earning a terminal (Ph.D.) degree in STEM.  Thus, the 2013-2015 cohorts upon the completion of their degrees will foster diversity and broaden the participation of minorities in STEM, similar to the 28 fellows with earned Ph.D. degrees from 17 different STEM disciplines. We have approached this overarching goal by rolling out a suite of programs that enable graduates to function at the highest levels of competency and professionalism. The programming suites include advanced transitional programs, staff and faculty mentoring, research lab rotations, research projects and professional interactions along with intensive evaluation protocol so as to ensure the completion of the Ph.D. program. Upon the completion of the Ph.D. program, the twelve 2013-2015 BD cohort will be prepared for STEM careers in the academia or industry. All the twelve fellows for the 2013-2015 BD cohort are still currently enrolled in the Ph.D. program, and thus retention remains at 100%.

Broader Impacts: The UIC BD activity broadened the participation of underrepresented individuals in STEM and related careers before, during, and after the STEM Ph.D. academic experience.  The UIC BD program has played a significant role in doubling the number of STEM doctorates earned by underrepresented minority at UIC since 2011. The 28 fellows who have earned their Ph.D. degrees cut across several disciplines and field in STEM which include, Mathematics/Statistics, Civil and Materials Engineering, Biochemistry & Molecular Genetics, Neuroscience, Physiology & Biophysics, Chemistry, Bioengineering, Pathology, Microbiology & Immunology, Bioengineering, and Pharmacology. The 2013-15 cohort included LSAMP scholars from five different alliances (Alabama, Illinois, Indiana, South Carolina, and Washington, DC).  UIC’s designations as a Minority Serving Institution (MSI) and Hispanic Serving Institution (HIS), and the depth and breadth of the University’s academic resources and support programming, articulate the University’s commitment to diversity in higher education (https://diversity.uic.edu/). Program successes and methods were widely disseminated to the National Science Foundation, institutions, and individuals through print and social media, at professional and research conferences, and recruitment venues. The sharing of information is intended to inform the literature and to encourage the development and implementation of similar programming and thus change the negative perceptions and stereotypes often associated with STEM higher education and the STEM workforce.
